title: The 2025 selection of premium summer cycling kit
content:
Cyclist
The 2025 selection of premium summer cycling kit

The perfect cycling kit will do three things: it will keep you comfortable for long periods on the bike; it will help you to go faster and perform at your best; it will look so damned good that other cyclists will go green with envy.

What follows is a taster of the latest road riding kit from ten of the sport’s big players, and it’s not hard to spot what the theme for the coming summer is going to be. Jerseys and bibs are understated and fuss-free, with minimal logos and coming in striking-but-tasteful block colours. It’s a long way from the heavily patterned and logo-strewn jerseys of, well… last year.

Of course, fashion doesn’t preclude technology, and the kit on display here boasts advances in materials for comfort, breathability and aerodynamics. Plus there is a new focus on sustainability, meaning cyclists can go green in other ways too.

So continue reading and take your pick. It looks like it’s going to be a bright summer for cycling.

Summer kit 2025 brands at a glance:

• Gobik
• Assos
• Bioracer
• Ekoï
• Lusso
• Castelli
• Santini
• Rapha
• Sportful
• Le Col

Gobik

Him

Gobik Attitude 2.0 jersey, €95, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Matt 2.0 bibshorts, €115, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Second Skin base layer, €48, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Vortex 2.0 Salt socks, €35, buy now at gobik.com

For the Ineos Grenadiers pro team, Gobik offers its race-oriented Lancer bib shorts, while the Matt 2.0 bib shorts shown here are more focussed on endurance. This is the Spanish brand’s ‘medium weight’ bibs for sweltering, long-distance rides.

The Matt 2.0 shorts are lined with a bi-elastic Lycra to alleviate lactic acid build-up and muscle tension. The material is also durable and highly resistant to pilling, scoring a maximum five on an ISO-approved scale.

To support, the chamois padding uses a multi-density foam to promote blood flow and recovery through its supple central channel and memory foam properties. Gobik also claims the graphene-infused fabric helps ward off bacterial growth and excess moisture – essential if the weather replicates Gobik’s native Spanish sunshine.

Her

Gobik CX Solid jersey, €85, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Matt 2.0 bibshorts, €115, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Second Skin base layer, €48, buy now at gobik.com
Gobik Vortex 2.0 Salt socks, €35, buy now at gobik.com

Gobik’s CX Solid jersey builds on the brand’s best-selling XC Pro to create a unisex garment for summer.

Designed to balance comfort and performance, it uses a stretchy polyamide-based fabric Gobik calls Evoflex, which boasts ‘multidirectional elasticity’. It provides a close fit that’s snug, breathable and aerodynamic without any awkward pinching.

The sleeves have a streamlined focus, having been lengthened to a laser-cut seamless finish closer to the elbows. Gobik says this smooth surface ‘eliminates friction, providing greater aerodynamics and comfort’.

On the aero front, the jersey has a hidden collar, thermosealed zip and flat-seam cargo pockets, plus it has 40+ UPF protection to protect you in the sun.

Assos

Him

Assos Mille GTS Jersey S11, £165, buy now at assos.com
Assos Summer NS Skin Layer, £65, buy now at assos.com
Assos Mille GTS Bibshorts S11, £215, buy now at assos.com
Assos Endurance socks S11 £16, buy now at assos.com

When you’re going a long way, it helps to have a jersey with a zip that doesn’t go all the way. Assos’s Mille GTS Jersey S11 is aimed at endurance rides in hot temperatures and comes with a ¾ length zip. This leaves a zip-free bottom section Assos calls zeroPressure Waist, which is very lightweight and breathable and cradles the stomach area to give stability and support without rippling.

The top section is made from a highly elastic fabric for an aerodynamic fit that still promotes comfort and cooling breathability, while the back section is made from Stabilizator V11, a textile that is light and cool but rigid enough to prevent sagging at the pockets. Throw in UPF50+ sun protection and you have a jersey that is perfect for the long days of summer.

Her

Assos UMA GT Jersey S11, £115, buy now at assos.com
Assos Summer NS Skin Layer, £65, buy now at assos.com
Assos Uma GTV Bibshorts C2 Evo, £265, buy now at assos.com
Assos Endurance socks S11, £16, buy now at assos.com

When comfort for the long haul is a priority, Assos’s UMA GTV bib shorts are a woman’s best friend. The Volkano main fabric is not only silky-smooth and compressive but also comes with UPF50+ sun protection, odour control and cooling properties to help on hot rides. Any long day in the saddle is going to require the occasional nature break, so the UMA GTV comes with Bisiclick, a pair of magnetic closures at the base of the bibstraps, which can be undone for easy removal.

The chamois is the plushest in Assos’s armoury, with two layers of shock-absorbing foam and cutaways to reduce friction. What’s more, the insert is only attached to the main fabric at the front and back, allowing it to ‘float’ so it moves with the body. 

With the UMA GTV bibs, no ride is too long.

Bioracer

Him

Bioracer Epic jersey, £76.57, buy now from shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Breeze base layer, £34.42, buy now at shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Epic bibshorts, £111.69, buy now at shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Tech socks, £20.37, buy now at shop.bioracer.com

Our priority was to develop the Epic bib shorts around the riding position, improving comfort, compression and breathability,’ says Bioracer’s product design manager, Ella Leys.

To that end, the shorts provide differing levels compression throughout and they have grippers placed directly into the fabric to eliminate extra seams and, in turn, improve comfort.

The Epic bib shorts are also Bioracer’s first to get the 3D WavePad chamois. ‘We worked with our pad supplier to create a chamois that is already shaped like a rider’s body,’ Leys says. ‘We performed some pressure tests to see the difference and figure out where to reduce friction and pressure points. The WavePad foam is a little harder, but the material is more breathable as it has holes through each foamed layer.’

Her

Bioracer Epic jersey, £76.57, buy now at shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Breeze base layer, £34.42, buy now at shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Epic bibshorts, £111.69, buy now at shop.bioracer.com
Bioracer Tech socks, £20.37, buy now at shop.bioracer.com

‘We translated the gradual compression from the bib shorts to the sleeves of the Epic jersey,’ says Leys. ‘The sleeves are also made using the same integrated silicone gripper as the bib shorts, so they remain in the correct place.’

The women’s Epic jersey, as worn by the Belgian national squad, uses a chevron-shaped gripper in the lower part of the jersey to create what Leys describes as a ‘flatter, more aggressive design’, which all helps when it comes to reducing drag and gaining speed.

‘A lot of women’s jerseys are made using a straight elastic band around the hem, which can create crinkles,’ Leys points out. ‘Our shape creates a clean look with a smoother shape, giving the body an extra accent around the hip.’

Ekoï

Him

Ekoï Perf Linear jersey, £121.98, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Racing Pro Outlast sleeveless base layer, £55.44, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Perf Gel Power Cross bibshorts, £188.52, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Perf Estate socks, £22.17, buy now at ekoi.com

The Perf Linear jersey has been designed to cope with high-intensity riding on the hottest summer days. To that end, Ekoï has used a specific technical material throughout.

‘We study any product that can offer a technological leap forward,’ say Ekoï product designers Eric Ceccon and Celine Milan. ‘This enables us to improve aerodynamics, thermoregulation, lightness, energy transfer and adaptation to changing weather conditions.’

The Perf Linear’s fabric is a microperforated polyester and elastane blend that provides muscle compression while also effectively evacuating body heat. In a bid to maximise speed, the elongated jersey sleeves are grooved with an aerodynamic pattern, and to minimise rubbing and irritation there is just one side seam on the torso.

Her

Ekoï Racing Outlast jersey, £166.34, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Perf Bra Emily, £38.80, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Perf Essential bibshorts, £210.70, buy now at ekoi.com
Ekoï Perf Estate socks, £22.17, buy now at ekoi.com

By incorporating the smart, natural, wax-based Outlast material into the fabric, Ekoï’s Racing jersey offers all-round temperature regulation that aims to significantly reduce sweat production and overheating when the mercury rises.

‘The natural wax encapsulated in the Outlast material melts to absorb excess heat and is stored in the textile,’ Ekoï’s product designers tell us. ‘Then it re-solidifies if the temperature drops to insulate the rider.’

As well as being versatile across a range of different seasons and providing UV50 sun protection, the jersey is optimised for comfort and
fit. Its sleeve panels begin at the neckline in a ‘raglan handlebar’ design to promote free movement and have been imprinted with a textured aerodynamic pattern.

Lusso

Him

Lusso Paragon jersey, £105, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Perform Summer base layer, £35, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Paragon Signature bibshorts, £200, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Paragon Summer socks, £12, buy now at lusso.bike

‘The Paragon jersey uses a micro-knit fabric from our suppliers in Italy that provides stretch and a soft feel. It’s twice as expensive as normal jersey fabrics but worth every penny, and our direct sales model keeps prices competitive anyway,’ says Lusso CEO Jake Wright. ‘As with all our kit, we construct it in-house in Manchester. It has a tailored, unisex fit to emphasise unrestrictive comfort, with features like raw-cut sleeves and minimal seams.’

The Paragon is available in six colour options: ‘We piece-dye the fabric, which gives a richer colour depth and means the colours stay bold after repeated washing,’ says Wright.

A high-quality YKK Vislon zip, three large-capacity pockets (with a hidden zipped extra one) and a rear reflective Lusso logo finish the Paragon off nicely.

Her

Lusso Paragon jersey, £105, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Paragon Sleeveless base layer, £40, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Paragon Comfort Break bibshorts, £145, buy now at lusso.bike
Lusso Paragon Summer socks, £12, buy now at lusso.bike

Lusso was one of the first brands to introduce an easy-to-use nature break feature to women’s bib shorts back in 2019. 

‘These shorts have benefitted from years of extensive feedback from the female cyclists in our team,’ says Wright. 

The Paragon Comfort Break bib shorts are the latest evolution of that design: ‘This version has a taller waistband for high coverage, but the straps are attached in a unique way to allow the waistband to be adjusted independently for maximum ease of use for the “Easypeesy” system.

‘There’s nothing fiddly to redo. The main fabric is a sturdier version of the micro-knit in the Paragon jersey, but with silicone injected into the fabric. This means we don’t have to sew in leg grippers and the hems sit seamlessly on the body.’

Castelli

Him

Castelli Aero Race 8S jersey, £169, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Pro Mesh 2.0 sleeveless base layer, £49, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Free Aero Race S bibshorts, £199, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Fast Feet 3 socks, £37, buy now at saddleback.co.uk

Castelli’s Aero kit is at the heart of its offering to pros and performance-minded amateurs, but never has it offered so much free speed. Take the Aero Race 8S jersey, as worn by Soudal-QuickStep.

‘The jersey is fastest at a speed that Remco Evenepoel would typically do in a solo break, so around 40kmh,’ says Castelli brand manager George Wise.‘

This is primarily achieved by the ribbed fabric on the sleeves and shoulders, where the ribs’ precise width and height has been optimised to trip the air to create low air pressure over the rider. The result is a 6% reduction in CdA compared to the previous jersey.’

It’s a similar story with the Free Aero Race S bib shorts, which use a textured pattern to reduce the garment’s coefficient of drag by 3% over the previous generation.

Her

Castelli Premio Evo W jersey, £215, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Pro Mesh W sleeveless base layer, £49, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Premio Evo W bibshorts, £279, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Castelli Premio Evo W socks £22, buy now at saddleback.co.uk

‘Fewer panels equals fewer seams equals more comfort,’ says Wise of the new Premio Evo bib shorts. ‘The key is the gradient-woven fabric, where the weave is progressively layered to create different stretch properties. A single panel of fabric can have different stretch properties in different areas, akin to having multiple fabrics without the seams.’

In essence that means the Premio Evo is mostly made up of one large panel of fabric that’s stretchier over the hip, for example, for less pedalling restriction, yet more compressive around the thigh for muscle support and better aerodynamics.

Paired with the Premio Evo jersey, Wise claims the overall outfit is superbly comfortable, fast wicking and very fast in wind-tunnel testing, and yet isn’t designed explicitly for racing. 

Santini

Him

Santini RTR jersey, £90, buy now at santinicycling.com
Santini RTR bibshorts, £150, buy now at santinicycling.com
Santini RTR Wind Jacket, £95, buy now at santinicycling.com

‘The concept behind the RTR [Ready To Ride] range was to create good-quality, highly durable garments in a large number of colours that can be mixed and matched to your taste,’ says Santini’s creative director, Fergus Niland. ‘The big difference is how we obtain those colours.’

The RTR collection is created using the ‘garment dyeing’ method, which means making each item in plain white and then dyeing the whole garment, rather than stitching together pre-dyed fabric. It allows Santini to produce only the most requested colours, avoiding overproduction and waste.

‘It means we can cut down massively on the amount of material that we have to buy in and the amount of energy and water we have to use to produce these products,’ says Niland. 

Her

Santini RTR jersey, £90, buy now at santinicycling.com
Santini RTR bibshorts, £150, buy now at santinicycling.com
Santini RTR Wind Jacket, £95, buy now at santinicycling.com

The Santini RTR bib shorts are produced using the same garment dyeing technique as the RTR jerseys.

‘As a manufacturer we have a responsibility to reduce the quantity of materials and garments that go to landfill,’ says Niland. ‘RTR has been in development for a good two years now because it’s not simple when you’re dealing with technical fabrics that stretch. To the best of my knowledge, in the world of cycling we’re the only ones doing this.’

The RTR bib shorts boast the same quality of fabric as other bibs in the Santini range, with ‘medium’ compression for comfort, excellent breathability, raw cut leg grippers and gender-specific chamois with gel cores to suit male and female riders. 

Rapha

Him

Rapha Men’s Pro Team Training jersey, £120, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Men’s Lightweight base layer, £55, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Men’s Pro Team Bib Shorts III, £240, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Men’s Pro Team socks extra long, £20, buy now at rapha.cc

‘Our goal is always to make our bibs feel invisible,’ says James Stannard, head of product management at Rapha. Thanks in part to exhaustive testing from sponsored rider Lachlan Morton during his colossal expeditions, the Pro Team Bib Shorts III have been developed as the brand’s comfiest yet.

‘Given the importance of this product in our lineup, we worked really closely with EF Education-EasyPost and our elite athletes to scrutinise every aspect of the bib,’ says Stannard. ‘We put over 400,000km into testing it.’

Answering the growing demand for longer bib shorts, they come in two lengths and with a reconfigured proprietary chamois pad and fewer fabric panels.

‘We’ve moved it on to a seamless construction that reduces bulk and significantly improves sweat-wicking and breathability,’ says Stannard. 

Her

Rapha Women’s Pro Team Training jersey, £120, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Women’s Pro Team Bib Shorts III, £240, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Women’s Lightweight base layer, £55, buy now at rapha.cc
Rapha Pro Team socks extra long £20, buy now at rapha.cc

More relaxed than Rapha’s all-out racing cut Pro jerseys, the Pro Team Training jersey has been reworked to provide both versatility and performance in warm weather. 

‘A key focus was comfort and fit,’ says Stannard. ‘The previous version had some relatively heavy elasticated construction at the arm and waistband, which we removed while also lowering the collar profile. Finally we added some length to the sleeves based on rider feedback, and increased the pocket size.’

Rapha is known for selecting Italian fabrics with baked-in technical attributes, and that continues in the Pro Team Training Jersey.

‘We use lightweight, high-stretch recycled polyester with elastane in the main body and sleeves, which is also relatively air permeable.’

Sportful

Him

Sportful SRK jersey, £75, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful Pro sleeveless base layer, £50, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful SRK bibshorts, £110, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful Pro socks, £16, buy now at saddleback.co.uk

‘SRK stands for Sportful Riders Kit. It’s a “grab and go” jersey and bib short combination designed to transcend disciplines,’ says Sportful brand manager George Wise. ‘Whether you want to do road or gravel, this is the kit. It’s performance cut but not race cut, using fabrics that are high-wicking but also more abrasion-resistant.’

That translates to a heavier-weight construction and a more relaxed fit than strict road kit – the sleeves have a banded, not laser cut hem for longevity, and the zip is longer to afford a more upright riding position. The bib shorts also feature two cargo pockets on the small of the back and a DMS seatpad, which is shorter and more padded at the sit bones, again to complement a more upright ride position.

The result, says Wise, ‘is a versatile kit that is exceptional value for money’.

Her

Sportful Supergiara Logo W jersey, £90, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful Pro W sleeveless base layer, £50, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful Supergiara 2 W bibshorts, £150, buy now at saddleback.co.uk
Sportful Pro socks, £16, buy now at saddleback.co.uk

‘Supergiara is aimed at riders who want technical kit with plenty of storage,’ says Wise. Born from the gravel scene’s increasing desire for adventure, this Supergiara kit uses various weights of fabric in key areas, such as the bib shorts’ side panels, which are denser to increase abrasion resistance.

‘The woven fabrics are also designed to optimise moisture wicking for better comfort during hot rides or races,’ says Wise. However, it’s arguably the pockets that set the Supergiara kit apart. Up top, the jersey features the traditional three rear pockets plus two side mesh pockets; below, the bib shorts have two cargo pockets on the thighs. 

‘Whether you’re a weekend gravel rider, a gravel pro doing the longest races or a road rider doing endurance events, the Supergiara kit is for you.’

Le Col

Him

Le Col Pro Aero jersey, £160, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Pro Air sleeveless base layer, £50, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Pro II bibshorts, £185, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Block Cycling socks, £17, buy now at lecol.cc

Le Col’s Pro II bib shorts are geared around going fast.

‘Having been tested in the wind-tunnel, these shorts are perfect for high-intensity efforts or long rides in the drops,’ says Charlotte Moulson, Le Col’s brand and product marketing manager. ‘They offer a sleek profile and second skin-like fit without compromising on comfort.’

This is achieved by cleverly cutting the shorts’ main panels to minimise seams when constructed, and using a close-fitting, warp-knit fabric that compresses and supports the working muscles. The comfort element is grounded in a top-quality chamois that uses memory foam inserts to help stabilise the wearer’s sit bones on the saddle and absorb vibrations when riding hard.

Her

Le Col Pro jersey, £145, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Pro Air Sleeveless base layer, £50, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Pro bibshorts, £185, buy now at lecol.cc
Le Col Cycling socks, £17, buy now at lecol.cc

‘We’re excited this year to introduce an even more refined iteration of our popular Pro jersey,’ says Moulson. 

Given that the rider makes up the bulk of the aerodynamic drag they face, the main updates that Le Col has built into the latest generation Pro jersey attempt to improve the rider’s efficiency in the wind.

‘A more articulated fit and sleek, bonded sleeves and hem streamline the jersey’s fit against the body,’ says Moulson. ‘Plus the rear pocket arrangement has been redesigned to be lighter but more robust, so kit can be stored more neatly without the jersey losing any of its intended fit.’

The jersey doesn’t represent speed achieved at any cost, however. The fabric itself, though tailored to be aero, is lightweight and therefore ventilates freely to avoid overheating.
